about.title: About Me

intro.paragraph1: I'm MartÃ­n Lucero, a digital educator, Web and Mobile Developer, and passionate about data analysis, artificial intelligence, and IT support. From General RodrÃ­guez, Buenos Aires, I transform ideas into technological solutions that teach, assist, and generate a positive impact on people. I find inspiration in nature, which reminds me that growthâ€”like in treesâ€”takes time, strong roots, and branches that open to change.
intro.paragraph2: With solid knowledge in Python, HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, and React, I develop responsive web applications, APIs, automation scripts, and data visualizations with a practical approach. I also have experience in technical support and helpdesk: troubleshooting, remote assistance, environment setup, software installation, and clear communication with users. I complement my profile with interface design, digital marketing, and SEO optimization.
intro.paragraph3: I am currently training as a teacher at the Universidad PedagÃ³gica Nacional, also finishing a Bachelor's in Information Systems at the Universidad Nacional de LujÃ¡n, and participating in an Artificial Intelligence diploma with Google and the Universidad Nacional del Delta. At the same time, I collaborate on real development and training projects, providing personalized classes, creating educational tools, and supporting others on their digital journey. My goal is clear: for technology to become increasingly accessible, useful, and human, in tune with learning, collaboration, and respect for our natural environment.

about.description: I'm a dedicated full-stack developer and systems engineering student with a passion for creating meaningful technology solutions. My journey combines formal education with hands-on experience in web development, artificial intelligence, and educational technology.
about.experience: My experience spans from building responsive web applications to developing AI-powered chatbots for academic institutions. I believe in the power of technology to transform education and am committed to bridging the gap between complex technical concepts and practical applications.
about.teaching: As an IT educator, I've had the privilege of teaching programming fundamentals and web development to aspiring developers. This experience has not only enhanced my communication skills but also deepened my understanding of technology from multiple perspectives.
about.philosophy: I approach every project with curiosity, attention to detail, and a commitment to quality. Whether it's developing a full-stack application or mentoring students, I strive to create solutions that are both technically sound and user-friendly.

sun.name: Sun
facts: It contains 99.8% of the total mass in the solar system.
Light takes about 8.3 minutes to travel from the Sun to Earth.
Its surface temperature is about 5,500 degrees Celsius.
The Sun is a yellow dwarf star, about 4.6 billion years old.
The core temperature reaches a staggering 15 million degrees Celsius.
It consists of about 73% hydrogen and 25% helium.
One million Earths could fit inside the Sun.
It rotates about once every 27 days at its equator.
The Sun is a nearly perfect sphere.
It generates energy through nuclear fusion in its core.

moon.name: Moon
facts: It is Earth's only natural satellite.
The Moon has no atmosphere, meaning no wind or weather.
Footprints on the Moon will stay there for millions of years.
The Moon's gravity is about 1/6th of Earth's gravity.
The same side of the Moon always faces Earth.
It causes the tides in our oceans.
There is water ice on the Moon's surface, mostly in craters.
It is the fifth largest moon in the solar system.
The Moon was likely formed by a giant impact with Earth.
A person would weigh much less on the Moon due to lower gravity.

mars.name: Mars
facts: Mars is home to Olympus Mons, the tallest volcano in the solar system.
A day on Mars is 24 hours and 37 minutes long.
It is known as the Red Planet due to iron oxide (rust) on its surface.
Mars has two moons: Phobos and Deimos.
It has seasons similar to Earth, but they last twice as long.
Valles Marineris is a canyon system on Mars as long as the USA.
Mars' atmosphere is 95% carbon dioxide.
Mars once had liquid water on its surface billions of years ago.
NASA currently has several rovers exploring the Martian surface.
It is about half the size of Earth.

mercury.name: Mercury
facts: Mercury is the smallest planet in our solar system.
It is the closest planet to the Sun.
A year on Mercury is only 88 Earth days long.
Mercury is the second densest planet after Earth.
Temperatures range from 430Â°C by day to -180Â°C at night.
It has no moons and no rings.
One day on Mercury lasts about 59 Earth days.
It has a very thin 'exosphere' rather than a thick atmosphere.
It is shrinking as its iron core slowly cools.
Despite its proximity to the Sun, it has ice in polar craters.

jupiter.name: Jupiter
facts: Jupiter is the largest planet in our solar system.
The Great Red Spot is a storm that has lasted for centuries.
Jupiter has 95 known moons.
It is a gas giant primarily made of hydrogen and helium.
Jupiter rotates once every 10 hours, the fastest in the solar system.
It has a very powerful magnetic field.
Its moon Ganymede is the largest moon in the solar system.
Jupiter has faint rings made of dust particles.
If Jupiter were 80 times more massive, it would be a star.
It has the strongest aurorae in the solar system.

venus.name: Venus
facts: Venus is the hottest planet in our solar system.
Venus rotates in the opposite direction to most other planets.
A day on Venus is longer than its year.
Its atmospheric pressure is 90 times greater than Earth's.
Venus is the second brightest object in the night sky.
It has no moons and no rings.
Venus is often called Earth's twin due to its similar size.
The surface is hot enough to melt lead (465Â°C).
It has clouds made of sulfuric acid.
Venus has thousands of volcanoes on its surface.

saturn.name: Saturn
facts: Saturn is famous for its massive and complex ring system.
It is so light it could float in water if there were an ocean big enough.
Saturn has at least 146 moons.
A day on Saturn is about 10.7 hours long.
The rings are made of billions of pieces of ice and rock.
Titan, its largest moon, has a thick nitrogen atmosphere.
Winds on Saturn can reach speeds of 1,800 kilometers per hour.
It has a giant hexagon-shaped storm at its North Pole.
Saturn is the second largest planet in our solar system.
It is a gas giant made mostly of hydrogen and helium.
